active_directory2 – Windows Active Directory Management¶

active_directory2.core.and_(*args, **kwargs)¶

Combine its arguments together as a valid LDAP AND-search. Positional arguments are taken to be strings already in the correct format (eg ‘displayName=tim*’) while keyword arguments will be converted into an equals condition for the names and values:

from active_directory.core import and_

print and_ (
  "whenCreated>=2010-01-01",
  displayName="tim*", objectCategory="person"
)

# &(whenCreated>=2010-01-01)(displayName=tim*)(objectCategory=person)
active_directory2.core.attribute_info(names=['*'], server=None, cred=None)¶

Return an iteration of name, dict pairs representing all the attributes named. The dict contains: lDAPDisplayName, instanceType, oMObjectClass, oMSyntax, attributeId, isSingleValued

Parameters:
  • names – A list of names for attributes to be returned [all attributes]
  • server – A specific server whose rootDSE is to be found [none - any server]
  • cred – anything accepted by credentials.credentials()
Returns:

An iteration of tuples containing (name, info)

  • adsi_flags – any combination of constants.AUTHENTICATION_TYPES

active_directory2.core.open_object(moniker, cred=None, flags=0)¶

Open an AD object represented by moniker, optionally authenticated. You will not normally call this yourself: it is used internally by the AD objects.

Parameters:
  • moniker – A complete AD moniker representing an AD object
  • cred – anything accepted by credentials.credentials()
  • flags – optional constants.AUTHENTICATION_TYPES flags. The credentials will set the appropriate flags for authentication, and server binding will be used if the moniker is server-based.
Returns:

a COM object corresponding to moniker and authenticated according to cred

This function is at the heart of authenticated access to AD offered by this package. The credentials work as follows:

  • cred is passed to credentials.credentials() for initial processing
  • If cred is now a credentials.Credentials object, this is used for authentication
  • moniker is parsed to determine the (optional) server name and the cache is checked for corresponding credentials.
  • If no cached credentials are found, passthrough authentication is assumed.

This will normally do what you expect. The default (passthrough) is far and away the most common. Specific credentials can either be passed in, eg, as a tuple, or can be held in the credentials cache and inferred from the server:

from active_directory2 import core, credentials

me = core.open_object ("LDAP://cn=Tim Golden,dc=goldent,dc=local")
me = core.open_object ("LDAP://cn=Tim Golden,dc=goldent,dc=local", cred=("goldent\tim", "pa55w0rd"))
with credentials.credentials (("goldent\tim", "5ecret", "testing")):
  me = core.open_object (core.root_moniker ())
me = core.open_object ("LDAP://testing/dc=test,dc=local", cred=credentials.Anonymous)
active_directory2.core.or_(*args, **kwargs)¶

Combine its arguments together as a valid LDAP OR-search. Positional arguments are taken to be strings already in the correct format (eg ‘displayName=tim*’) while keyword arguments will be converted into an equals condition for the names and values:

from active_directory.core import or_

print or_ (
  "whenCreated>=2010-01-01",
  objectCategory="person"
)

# |(whenCreated>=2010-01-01)(objectCategory=person)
active_directory2.core.query(query_string, connection=None, **command_properties)¶

Basic AD query, passing a raw query string straight through to an Active Directory, optionally using a (possibly pre-authenticated) connection or creating one on demand. command_properties may be specified which will be passed through to the ADO command with underscores replaced by spaces. Useful values include:

page_size How many records to return in one go
size_limit Stop after returning this many records
cache_results Boolean: cache results; turn off if a large result
time_limit Stop returning records after this many seconds
timeout Stop waiting for the records to start after this many seconds
asynchronous Boolean: Start returning records immediately
sort_on field name to sort on
Parameters:
  • query_string – An AD query string in any acceptable format. See query_string() for an easy way of producing this
  • connection – (optional) An ADODB.Connection, as provided by connect(). If this is supplied it will be used and not closed. If it is not supplied, a default connection will be created, used and then closed.
  • command_properties – A collection of keywords which will be passed through to the ADO query as Properties.
active_directory2.core.query_string(filter='', base=None, attributes=[u'ADsPath'], scope=u'Subtree', range=None)¶

Easy way to produce a valid AD query string, with meaningful defaults. This is the first parameter to the query() function so the following will yield the display name of every user in the domain:

import active_directory as ad

qs = ad.query_string (filter="(objectClass=User)", attributes=["displayName"])
for u in ad.query (qs):
  print u['displayName']
Parameters:
  • filter – An AD filter string to limit the search [no filter]. The or_() and and_() functions provide an easy way to produce a valid filter, optionally combined with the schema class.
  • base – An LDAP:// moniker representing the starting point of the search [domain root]
  • attributes – Iterable of attribute names [ADsPath]
  • scope – One of - Subtree, Base, OneLevel. Subtree (the default) is the most common and does the search you expect. OneLevel enumerates the children of the base item. Base checks for the existence of the object itself. [Subtree].
  • range – Limit the number of returns of multivalued attributes [no range]

Returns:

The COM Object corresponding to the RootDSE for the server or domain

Return the moniker representing the domain specified by a server and a scheme (typically LDAP: or GC:). If you need the corresponding object, use root_obj().

Parameters:
  • server – A specific server whose rootDSE is to be found [none - any server]
  • scheme – Typically LDAP: or GC: [LDAP:]
Returns:

The moniker corresponding to the domain

Return the COM object representing the domain specified by a server and a scheme (typically LDAP: or GC:), optionally authenticated. If you only need the moniker, use root_moniker().

Parameters:
  • server – A specific server whose rootDSE is to be found [none - any server]
  • scheme – Typically LDAP: or GC: [LDAP:]
  • cred – anything accepted by credentials.credentials()
Returns:

The COM object corresponding to the domain

class active_directory2.adbase.ADBase(obj, cred=None)¶

A slender wrapper around an AD COM object.

Attributes can be read, set and cleared. If the underlying object is a container it can be iterated over and subobjects can be retrieved, added and removed. It can also be walked (in the style of Python’s os.walk) and flattened: walk(), flat().

Pretty-printing to stdout is via the dump() method.

There is simple searching with filters, returning the results as objects if its own type: search(), find().

The underlying object can itself be deleted via delete()

No validation is done of the names passed and an no conversions of the values. It can be used alone (most easily via the adbase() function which takes an AD path and returns an ADBase object). It also provides the basis for the ADObject class.

Exceptions¶

All COM-related exceptions are wrapped in active_directory2.exc.ActiveDirectoryError or one of its subclasses. Therefore you can safely trap active_directory2.exc.ActiveDirectoryError as a root exception.

exception active_directory2.exc.ActiveDirectoryError¶

Base class for all AD Exceptions
